name: Twitter
brand:
Regarding the name:
"...we came across the word 'twitter', and it was just perfect. The definition was 'a short burst of inconsequential information,' and 'chirps from birds'. And that's exactly what the product was." – Jack Dorsey (http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2009/02/twitter-creator.html)

Regarding the bird:
On June 5, 2012, Twitter unveiled its third logo redesign, simply named as the "Twitter Bird," as the sole symbol for the company's branding. The new logo replaces Twitter's lowercase "t" and the old bird. The new bird resembles the older logo but appears to be slimmer and is also tilted upward.

A quote from the LA Times:
"Whether soaring high above the Earth to take in a broad view, or flocking with other birds to achieve a common purpose, a bird in flight is the ultimate representation of freedom, hope and limitless possibility," Doug Bowman (the company's creative director) said. 
(http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-twitter-new-bird-20120606,0,2138652.story)

Twitter is mainly used by older adults who might not have used other social sites before Twitter, said Jeremiah Owyang, an industry analyst studying social media. history:
From Wikipedia:

Twitter rose out of a brainstorming session by board members of the podcasting company Odeo, and the first Tweet went out on March 21, 2006 by Jack Dorsey. It says "just setting up my twttr". (https://twitter.com/jack/status/20). The full version, then called twttr, was introduced publicly on July 15, 2006. (http://techcrunch.com/2006/07/15/is-twttr-interesting/)

In October 2006, Biz Stone, Evan Williams, Dorsey, and other members of Odeo formed Obvious Corporation and acquired Odeo and all of its assets – including Odeo.com and Twitter.com – from the investors and shareholders.[17] Williams fired Glass who was silent about his part in Twitter's startup until 2011.[18] Twitter spun off into its own company in April 2007.[19]

The tipping point for Twitter's popularity was the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive (SXSWi) conference. During the event, Twitter usage increased from 20,000 tweets per day to 60,000.[20] "The Twitter people cleverly placed two 60-inch plasma screens in the conference hallways, exclusively streaming Twitter messages," remarked Newsweek's Steven Levy. "Hundreds of conference-goers kept tabs on each other via constant twitters. Panelists and speakers mentioned the service, and the bloggers in attendance touted it."[21]

The first unassisted off-Earth Twitter message was posted from the International Space Station by NASA astronaut T. J. Creamer on January 22, 2010.[24] By late November 2010, an average of a dozen updates per day were posted on the astronauts' communal account, @NASA_Astronauts. NASA has also hosted over 25 "tweetups", events that provide guests with VIP access to NASA facilities and speakers with the goal of leveraging participants' social networks to further the outreach goals of NASA.

In August 2010, the company appointed Adam Bain as President of Revenue from News Corp.'s Fox Audience Network.[25]

On September 14, 2010, Twitter launched a redesigned site[26] including a new logo.[citation needed]

As of March 2011, that was about 140 million tweets posted daily.[30] As noted on Compete.com, Twitter moved up to the third-highest-ranking social networking site in January 2009 from its previous rank of twenty-second.[31]

When American singer Michael Jackson died on June 25, 2009, Twitter servers crashed after users were updating their status to include the words "Michael Jackson" at a rate of 100,000 tweets per hour.[35]

On March 21, 2012, Twitter celebrated its sixth birthday while also announcing that it has 140 million users and sees 340 million tweets per day. The number of users is up 40% from their September 2011 number, which was said to have been at 100 million at the time.[43]
resource:
It also serves as an index of important cultural and political concerns: 
'On April 30, 2009, Twitter adjusted its web interface, adding a search bar and a sidebar of "trending topics" — the most common phrases appearing in messages. Biz Stone explains that all messages are instantly indexed and that "with this newly launched feature, Twitter has become something unexpectedly important – a discovery engine for finding out what is happening right now."[122]'
http://blog.twitter.com/2009/04/twitter-search-for-everyone.html

On June 1, 2011, Twitter announced its own integrated photo-sharing service that enables users to upload a photo and attach it to a Tweet right from Twitter.com.[177] Users now also have the ability to add pictures to Twitter's search by adding hashtags to the tweet.[178] Twitter also plans to provide photo galleries designed to gather and syndicate all photos that a user has uploaded on Twitter and third-party services such as TwitPic.[178]

Twitter messages are by default public, but users can set their privacy settings to allow their tweets to be visible to only select users, and can also send private messages. Twitter collects personally identifiable information about its users and shares it with third parties. The service reserves the right to sell this information as an asset if the company changes hands.[144] While Twitter displays no advertising, advertisers can target users based on their history of tweets and may quote tweets in ads[145] directed specifically to the user.
https://twitter.com/privacy/
http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/16/advertisers-are-watching-your-every-tweet/

On May 17, 2012, Twitter announced it would implement the "Do Not Track" privacy option, a cookie-blocking feature found in Mozilla's Firefox browser. The "Do Not Track" feature works only on sites that have agreed to the service.
http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/17/twitter-implements-do-not-track-privacy-option/

tasks:
Tweeting.

registered users can post tweets through the website interface, SMS, or a range of apps for mobile devices.

Users can group posts together by topic or type by use of hashtags – words or phrases prefixed with a "#" sign. Similarly, the "@" sign followed by a username is used for mentioning or replying to other users.[66] To repost a message from another Twitter user, and share it with one's own followers, the retweet function is symbolized by "RT" in the message.'
alliances:
On February 21, 2012, it was announced that Twitter and Yandex agreed to a partnership. Yandex, a Russian search engine, finds value within the partnership due to Twitter’s real time news feeds. Twitter’s director of business development explained that it is important to have Twitter content where Twitter users go.[42]
http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/21/twitter-yandex-idUSL5E8DK89H20120221

On June 4, 2012, Twitter announced the purchase of Washington, D.C. based web design agency Nclud. Upon the purchase, Nclud's co-founder and director of brand experience, Martin Ringlein, was named Twitter's new design manager.[46]
http://techcrunch.com/2012/06/04/twitter-buys-design-agency-nclud-appoints-co-founder-twitters-new-design-manager/

On January 23, 2012, it was reported that Twitter will be acquiring Dasient, a startup that offers malware protection for businesses. Twitter hopes that Dasient will help remove hateful advertisers on the website.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/01/24/twitter-dasient-security-startup_n_1227842.html
sponsors:
Its second B round of funding in 2008 was for US$22 million[100] and its third C round of funding in 2009 was for US$35 million from Institutional Venture Partners and Benchmark Capital along with an undisclosed amount from other investors including Union Square Ventures, Spark Capital and Insight Venture Partners.[99] Twitter is backed by Union Square Ventures, Digital Garage, Spark Capital, and Bezos Expeditions.[101]

 In August, 2010 Twitter announced a "significant" investment lead by Digital Sky Technologies that, at US$800 million, was reported to be the largest venture round in history.[106]

In December 2011, the Saudi prince Alwaleed bin Talal invested $300 million in Twitter.

Since its launch, Twitter has become one of the top 10 most visited websites on the Internet, and has been described as "the SMS of the Internet."[5][10]  http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/twitter.com

In March 2012, Twitter became available in Arabic, Farsi, Hebrew and Urdu, the first right-to-left language versions of the site. About 13,000 volunteers helped with translating the menu options.[123] In August 2012, beta support for Basque, Czech and Greek was added, making the site available in 33 different languages.[124]
